title: Ticket #24: Port Condor to Debian 5.0 (Lenny)
description:
LIGO has made a formal request for Condor to be fully ported to the Debian 5.0 (Lenny) distribution of Linux to be ready to test by March 2009.

Usable machines in NMI:
x86_debian_5.0 nmi-0199 x86
x86_64_debian_5.0 nmi-0200 x86_64

2009-Feb-09 16:17:58 by psilord:
The tools are installed.

I need them to get the patched glibc 2.7-18 (as of today) source so I can incorporate it into Condor's externals.

Another way to do this is: 

> apt-get source glibc
> cd glibc-2.7
> dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b

To get the patched source specifically, one can also do this: 

'get the glibc .dsc .orig-tar.gz and .diff.gz files'
> dpkg-source -x glibc_2.7-18.dsc

Then build the source the same way as above.

2009-Feb-09 16:48:42 by psilord:
The diff.gz file is a set of patches, and that is placed into the glibc-2.7 directory, dpkg-build-package actually applies the patches to the tree. Notice the distinction.

2009-Feb-18 14:42:51 by psilord:
Ok, it is pretty ugly to getting a patched glibc extracted out of the debian system.

Basically, on deb 5.0 x86 you: 

# This is for tcsh
apt-get source glibc
cd glibc-2.7
(dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b) |& tee /tmp/build.out # wait for completion
cd build-tree/glibc-2.7 # This is the patched source
rm -rf .pc # get rid of quilt's patch cache which tar doesn't like
rm -rf debian
cp -Rp ../../debian . # This uses the headers on the machine you build
cd ..
head i386-686/config.log # save the configure line
cd ..
mv glibc-2.7 glibc-2.7-18 # name it what we need it to be
tar zcf glibc-2.7-18.tar.gz glibc-2.7-18
mv glibc-2.7-18 glibc-2.7

# Now, when editing the build-glibc-* file for the externals, dig through
# /tmp/build.out and get out the full configure line and make arguments.
# Compare and contrast with the configure line from config.log and pick the
# right stuff. Then add the additional command line arguments in our build
# script as delineated by a previous glibc build.

And on deb 5 x86_64, you: 

# This is for tcsh
apt-get source glibc
cd glibc-2.7
(dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b) |& tee /tmp/build.out # wait for completion
cd build-tree/glibc-2.7 # This is the patched source
rm -rf .pc # get rid of quilt's patch cache which tar doesn't like
rm -rf debian
cp -Rp ../../debian . # This uses the headers on the machine you build
cd ..
head amd64-libc/config.log # save the configure line
cd ..
mv glibc-2.7 glibc-2.7-18 # name it what we need it to be
tar zcf glibc-2.7-18.tar.gz glibc-2.7-18
mv glibc-2.7-18 glibc-2.7

# Now, when editing the build-glibc-* file for the externals, dig through
# /tmp/build.out and get out the full configure line and make arguments.
# Compare and contrast with the configure line from config.log and pick the
# right stuff. Then add the additional command line arguments in our build
# script as delineated by a previous glibc build.

2009-Mar-12 10:51:05 by psilord:
After messing about online and reading the GCC Inline Tutorial. I've constructed this patch, which should encrypt/decrypt the pointers I need out of the jmp buf: 

/* 24 is the magic number which represents the offset to the pointer_guard
variable in a tcbhead_t structure. This location contains the encryption
value which is used to encrypt runtime pointers in glibc such as the
stack location in the jump buf structure. The address to the start of
the tcbhead structure is stored in the %gs register.
*/

#if defined(GLIBC27)
# ifdef __ASSEMBLER__
#  define PTR_ENCRYPT(reg)  \
                xorl %gs:24, reg;   \
                roll $9, reg
#  define PTR_DECRYPT(reg)  \
                rorl $9, reg;       \
                xorl %gs:24, reg
# else
#  define PTR_ENCRYPT(ptr)  \
                asm ("xorl %%gs:24, %0\n"   \
                     "roll $9, %0"          \
                     : "=r" (ptr)           \
                     : "0" (ptr))
#  define PTR_DECRYPT(ptr)  \
                asm ("rorl $9, %0\n"    \
                     "xorl %%gs:24, %0" \
                     : "=r" (ptr)       \
                     : "0" (ptr))
# endif
#else

# ifdef __ASSEMBLER__
#  define PTR_ENCRYPT(x)
#  define PTR_DECRYPT(x)
# else
#  define PTR_ENCRYPT(x) x
#  define PTR_DECRYPT(x) x
# endif
#endif
